importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The scheduled opening date of the temporary exhibition at CajaGranada Cultural Center in Granada, marking the timeline of the missing artwork's disappearance.
The date of the article's publication, indicating the current status of the investigation into the missing Picasso painting.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period just before the exhibition's scheduled opening, during which the painting was delivered and stored under video surveillance.
The time period during which the delivery and unpacking process occurred, including the weekend when no incidents were reported.

keyTakeAways: A Picasso painting, 'Still Life with Guitar' (1919), went missing during transport to a temporary exhibition in Granada, Spain.
The painting was insured for 600,000 euros (~$700,000) and was delivered under video surveillance to the CajaGranada Cultural Center.
All deliveries were processed in a single, continuous movement with full surveillance, yet the artwork disappeared during unpacking on Monday, October 13, 2025.
No incidents were reported during the weekend, and video recordings show no signs of theft or tampering.
Spanish police are investigating the disappearance and have added the painting to the international database of stolen artworks.
Picasso’s works are frequently targeted by thieves due to their high value and historical significance.
Historical examples include the recovery of 'Portrait of Dora Maar' in 2019 and 'Head of a Woman' in 2021, showing a pattern of Picasso artwork theft and recovery.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 1919 gouache painting by Pablo Picasso, titled 'Still Life with Guitar' (Naturaleza muerta con guitarra), went missing during the transport to a temporary exhibition at the CajaGranada Cultural Center in Granada, Spain. The painting, valued at 600,000 euros ($700,000), was delivered under video surveillance from Madrid and was supposed to be unveiled on October 9, 2025. After being unpacked on Monday, October 13, 2025, the painting was found missing. Spanish police have launched an investigation to determine when and where it disappeared, and the artwork has been added to the international database of stolen artworks. The case highlights the ongoing threat of theft targeting Picasso’s valuable and iconic works, with historical examples including recoveries of 'Portrait of Dora Maar' in 2019, 'Head of a Woman' in 2021, and 'Tête' in 2024.
title: Picasso painting goes missing en route to exhibition
